title: Geoffrey Arthur
text:
Sir Geoffrey George Arthur, (19 March 1920 – 15 May 1984) was a British diplomat and <a href="Academic%20administration">academic administrator</a>. After a career in the <a href="Foreign%20Office">Foreign Office</a>, he was <a href="Master%20%28college%29">Master</a> of <a href="Pembroke%20College%2C%20Oxford">Pembroke College, Oxford</a> from 1975 until his death in 1984.
Early life and education.
He was educated at <a href="Ashby%20School">Ashby-de-la-Zouch Grammar School</a> and <a href="Christ%20Church%2C%20Oxford">Christ Church, Oxford</a>. His university education was interrupted by war service. He served in Egypt, Iran and Iraq, and on returning to Oxford, transferred from studying classics to Persian and Arabic. He graduated with first class honours.
Career.
He joined the Foreign Office in 1947, serving in Baghdad, Ankara, Cairo and Bonn. He was <a href="List%20of%20ambassadors%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom%20to%20Kuwait">Ambassador to Kuwait</a> from 1967 to 1970. From 1970 to 1971, he was the last <a href="Persian%20Gulf%20Residency">Political Resident in the Persian Gulf</a> and oversaw the break up of the British territory in the <a href="Persian%20Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> into the independent states of <a href="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>, <a href="Qatar">Qatar</a>, and the <a href="United%20Arab%20Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>. His final civil service appointment was as Chair of the <a href="Joint%20Intelligence%20Committee%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Joint Intelligence Committee</a>, serving between 1973 and 1975.
In 1975, he was elected <a href="Master%20%28college%29">Master</a> of <a href="Pembroke%20College%2C%20Oxford">Pembroke College, Oxford</a>. He was also on the governing body of <a href="Abingdon%20School">Abingdon School</a> from 1978. 
Personal life.
In 1946, Arthur married Margaret, daughter of T. A. Woodcock (former headteacher of Ashby School). They had no children.
He died on 15 May 1984, aged 64, after a short illness. A memorial serve was held at <a href="Christ%20Church%20Cathedral%2C%20Oxford">Christ Church Cathedral, Oxford</a>.
